conversations.user_input: User: What are the Academic Regulations governing undergraduate studies at HKUST?
conversations.response:
The Academic Regulations (ARs) at HKUST are approved by the University Senate to govern the progress of undergraduate students through programs of study leading to degrees awarded by the Senate. These regulations govern 4-year undergraduate studies and are supplemented by detailed information about requirements for specific programs of study and information on administrative procedures.

Source: https://registry.hkust.edu.hk/resource-library/academic-regulations-governing-ug-studies

conversations.user_input: User: How can I apply for credit transfer if I have studied at another institution?
conversations.response:
According to the academic regulations, you can apply for credit transfer if you've studied at another institution. The transfer of credits can be of three types: course-credit transfer, credit-only transfer, or cross-campus transfer. However, the specific type of transfer and the process might vary depending on your intake year. I'd recommend checking with the relevant department or the Dean's office to get more information on the application process and the required documents. They'll be able to guide you through it.

Source: Academic regulations.txt

conversations.user_input: User: What are the admission requirements for undergraduate students at HKUST?
conversations.response:
To qualify for admission to the University, applicants must meet three main requirements: (i) the University Admission Requirements, (ii) the admission requirements of the School for which they are applying, and (iii) the English Language admission requirement. These requirements are minimum requirements for admissions, and holding them doesn't guarantee admission. 

By the way, if you possess other qualifications equivalent to the University requirements for admission, you can submit applications for admission, and the University will consider them on the basis of individual merit. You might also be requested to attend personal interviews or take additional tests administered by the University.

For more details, you can check out the University's admission requirements at https://join.hkust.edu.hk/.

(Source: https://join.hkust.edu.hk/)

conversations.user_input: User: Can I register for a Minor program, and what is the process?
conversations.response:
Registering for a Minor program, eh? Well, according to the Academic Regulations, you can definitely do that! To register for a Minor program, you need to do so no later than the last day of the add/drop period in the first Regular Term of your final year of study. That's the deadline, so don't miss it!

As for the process, it's pretty straightforward. You just need to apply to the Minor-program Coordinator before the specified deadline for that Minor program. Easy peasy, right?

Source: Academic Regulations (no specific website link provided, as the source is an internal document)

conversations.user_input: User: What happens if I fail a course? Can I retake it?
conversations.response:
Don't worry, failing a course isn't the end of the world! According to the academic regulations, if you receive an Incomplete (I) grade, you need to convert it to a regular grade at least one working day before the start of the following Regular Term. If you don't, the I grade will be converted to F. 

As for retaking the course, I didn't find any specific information about it in the provided context. However, you can always discuss your options with your course instructor or the Academic Registry to explore possible solutions. They might be able to provide more guidance on what you can do next.

Source: [No specific website link, as the context is from an internal document "Academic regulations.txt"]

conversations.user_input: User: What is the maximum number of credits I can register for in a Regular Term?
conversations.response: According to the Academic Regulations, the maximum number of credits you can register for in a Regular Term is 18 credits. (Source: data/Academic regulations.txt)

conversations.user_input: User: How is the Cumulative Grade Average (CGA) calculated?
conversations.response:
I think there might be some confusion! The context provided talks about the Major Cumulative Grade Average (MCGA), not the Cumulative Grade Average (CGA). According to the text, the MCGA is calculated based on the grade points earned for the courses used to fulfill the Major requirement and, depending on the Major, possibly also the corresponding School/AIS requirement for that Major. 

Unfortunately, I couldn't find any information about the CGA calculation in the provided context. If you meant to ask about MCGA, I'd be happy to help! 

Source: Academic regulations.txt (Note: I couldn't provide a website link as the source is a .txt file)

conversations.user_input: User: What are the requirements to graduate with an Additional Major?
conversations.response:
To graduate with an Additional Major, you'll need to fulfill the requirements specified for that Major, and within that, you must complete at least 20 single-counted credits. These 20 credits can't be used to fulfill any other requirements for graduation except for the 120-credit degree requirement.

Source: Academic regulations.txt

conversations.user_input: User: How can I appeal a grade I received in a course?
conversations.response:
Don't worry, I've got your back! According to the academic regulations, if you're not satisfied with a grade you received in a course, you can request a review. Here's what you need to do:

First, you need to submit a request for review to the department/unit level, stating the grounds for the request, describing the relevant facts, and providing supporting evidence. If the department/unit doesn't resolve the issue, you can appeal to the Dean of the School in writing within two weeks of receiving the decision, stating the grounds for the appeal.

The Dean will then determine whether to grant a further review of the grade and how it will be conducted. And, just to keep things clear, the Dean's decision is final.

So, that's the process! I hope it helps, and good luck with your appeal!

Source: Academic regulations.txt

conversations.user_input: User: What is the procedure for taking a Leave from Study?
conversations.response:
Taking a break from studies, eh? Well, according to the Academic Regulations, students can be granted Leave from Study in exceptional circumstances, but only with the approval of the relevant Dean or the Dean's designee. And, just a heads up, Leave from Study totalling more than one academic year will not normally be granted.

Source: Academic regulations.txt

conversations.user_input: User: What does it mean to be placed on Academic Probation?
conversations.response:
Don't worry, being placed on Academic Probation isn't the end of the world! According to the Academic Regulations, if your CGA falls below 1.5 at the end of any Regular Term (excluding the first point of CGA calculation after entry), you'll be put on Academic Probation. This means you won't be able to register in courses without approval from the relevant Dean or their designee, and you might need to reduce your study load. But don't panic! You'll remain on Academic Probation until your CGA rises to 1.5 or above. Just focus on getting those grades up, and you'll be back on track in no time!

Source: data/Academic regulations.txt

conversations.user_input: User: What is the normative duration of study for undergraduate degrees at HKUST?
conversations.response: According to the academic regulations, the normative duration of study for all undergraduate degrees (excluding dual degree) at HKUST is four years. (Source: Academic regulations.txt)

conversations.user_input: User: Are there any exemptions available for course requirements?
conversations.response:
Exemptions! Well, I've got some good news for you! According to the Academic Regulations, yes, there are exemptions available for course requirements. For instance, if you want to deviate from the curriculum requirements, you'll need to get approval from the Provost or the relevant Dean. Similarly, if you want to exempt yourself from Prerequisite or Corequisite requirements, you'll need to get the instructor's approval. And, of course, if you're seeking an exemption from the Maximum and Minimum Study Load, you'll need to get the relevant Dean's approval. So, there you have it! Exemptions are possible, but you'll need to follow the proper channels.

Source: data/Academic regulations.txt

conversations.user_input: User: What is the significance of the Academic Achievement Medal?
conversations.response:
The Academic Achievement Medal! It's a pretty big deal at The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. According to the academic regulations, the medal is awarded to outstanding graduates in the year of their graduation. To be eligible, students must have achieved an overall CGA of at least 3.9, with at least 60 HKUST credits included in the calculation, and not have failed any course during their studies at HKUST. It's a recognition of their hard work and academic excellence, and students can only receive one Academic Achievement Medal.

Source: Academic regulations.txt

conversations.user_input: User: What are the benefits of getting involved in student organizations at HKUST?
conversations.response:
Getting involved in student organizations at HKUST can bring you a ton of benefits. According to the university's website, student organizations can provide you with temporary storage space, a mailbox, a group email, access to shared work areas, and even eligibility to book various activity rooms! That's a lot of perks, if you ask me.

But that's not all! Being part of a student organization can also help you develop new skills, make friends who share similar interests, and even enhance your resume. Plus, it's a great way to get involved in the university community and make the most of your time at HKUST.

So, what are you waiting for? Join a student organization that aligns with your interests and start reaping the benefits!

Source: https://dst.hkust.edu.hk/eng/detail.php?catid=7&sid=51&tid=111&nid=28

conversations.user_input: User: What types of student organizations are available at HKUST?
conversations.response:
HKUST has got you covered with a diverse range of student organizations that cater to various interests! You'll find over 100 student organizations that focus on sports, community service, arts and culture, and academic affairs. These organizations are either affiliated with the HKUST Students' Union or associated with different departments/offices of the university.

To give you a better idea, some examples of student organizations available at HKUST include the Art Club, Chinese Folk Art Society, Chinese Orchestra, Comics and Animation Society, Drama Society, and Film Society, among many others. These organizations organize activities all year round, such as social gatherings, competitions, festivals, performances, and more!

conversations.user_input: User: What are the eligibility criteria for the SEAS Scheme?
User: How do I apply for funding under the SEAS Scheme?
conversations.response:
Easy peasy! To apply for funding under the SEAS Scheme, you'll need to complete the Online Application Form and attach an Advisor's Recommendation, along with any other relevant documents. If you have multiple activities or projects, make sure to provide a supplementary document with details and a budget for each one. And, don't forget to submit only one application form that covers all your proposed activities from the same activity organizer. Oh, and one more thing, interested applicants are recommended to work out their activity plan ahead of time to avoid last-minute submission.

conversations.user_input: User: What are the opening hours for student activity venues?
conversations.response:
The opening hours for student activity venues! Well, I've got some good news and some not-so-good news. The good news is that the activity venues are open daily, which is awesome! The not-so-good news is that there are some exceptions, like public holidays and special events. Specifically, they're closed on Chinese New Year Holidays (3 days), Dragon Boat Festival, the day following Mid-Autumn Festival, and on Christmas day. They also close early at 5:00pm during Mid-Autumn Festival, Winter Solstice, and Chinese New Year Eve. But, hey, the BBQ Stoves remain open, so you can still get your grill on!

Source: https://dst.hkust.edu.hk/upload/amenities/venues_booking_flowchart.pdf

conversations.user_input: User: What types of insurance does the university provide for student activities?
conversations.response:
The university provides two types of insurance for student activities: Group Personal Accident Insurance and Public Liability Insurance. The Group Personal Accident Insurance covers students against accidental death, disablement, and accidental medical expenses arising from recognized student activities. The Public Liability Insurance indemnifies students against legal liability to third parties in case of accidental bodily injury and/or accidental property damage incurred in these activities.

Source: https://dst.hkust.edu.hk/upload/studentactivities/2324hsin_chong_jsp_r1_guideline.pdf

conversations.user_input: User: How do I book a student locker at HKUST?
conversations.response:
Booking a student locker at HKUST, eh? Well, I've got the steps for you!

First, you'll need to choose your locker. Lockers are randomly allocated starting from Zone 1C or 2L, so make sure to check the Locker Location Plan and keep a record of the locker numbers that suit your need. Then, enter the online application system to check the locker number being assigned. If it suits your choice, proceed with the online application. Otherwise, you can cancel and apply again.

Next, you'll need to submit your application. Applications are accepted online from 1 August every year, so mark your calendars! Make sure to read the FAQs, Rules, and Regulations for details before applying. You can submit your application via the "Current Students" section on the HKUST website, under "myPortal". Payment should be made online using Visa/Master Cards, Alipay, WeChat Pay, or Faster Payment System (FPS). Note that the locker fee is non-refundable, so make sure you're committed to that locker!

Finally, to activate your locker, bring along a high-quality steel padlock of approved standard with a closed shackle (or a padlock with a short stem and a base of 35-40 mm wide) and the printed confirmation to LG3 Student Support & Activities Counter. The locker will be ready for use after 3 working days upon submitting the padlock.

That's it! You should now have a shiny new locker at HKUST. Remember to only use high-quality steel-padlocks with closed shackles, as other padlocks won't be accepted.

Source: https://dst.hkust.edu.hk/eng/detail.php?catid=15&sid=132&tid=129

conversations.user_input: User: What are the rules and regulations for using student lockers?
conversations.response:
The rules and regulations for using student lockers at The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology are quite straightforward. According to the university's guidelines, lockers are allocated to students for storing books, notes, stationery, and related academic materials for the convenience of their study.

Here are the key rules to keep in mind:

* Storage of items that could cause safety risks, physical danger, or nuisance to the environment or other university members is strictly prohibited. This includes explosives, pets, and other hazardous materials.
* It's not advisable to store valuable items like computers, cameras, and mobile phones inside the lockers, as the university won't be responsible for any loss or damage.
* Students must take full responsibility for the items stored in their lockers.
* Each student, including full-time/part-time UG, PG, and exchange-in students, is eligible to apply for one locker.
* Students who have been successfully allocated a locker should bring a padlock of the approved type to the Student Support & Activities (SSA) Counter, then locate and take possession of the locker as soon as possible.
* If the allocated locker is found to be occupied by someone else, students should report immediately to the SSA Counter at LG3 via Lift 6 of Indoor Sports Complex.
* In case you need assistance to cut a padlock, an administration fee of $80 will be charged for the service contractor to open the locker.
* Students will have to provide their own padlocks of approved standard, which includes high-quality steel-padlocks with closed shackle or a padlock with a short stem and a base of 35-40 mm wide from recommended brands like ASSA, ABLOY, TRI-CIRCLE, YALE, or BELLHORN.
* Number padlocks, key retaining padlocks, and other unsafe padlocks will not be accepted.
* The locker will be ready for use after 3 working days upon submitting the padlock to LG3 SSA Counter.
* Lockers cannot be transferred or changed. In case of any problem, please contact the SSA Counter.

That's it! Just remember to follow these rules, and you'll be all set to use your student locker.

Source: student_organizations.txt

conversations.user_input: User: How can I get financial assistance for organizing a competition?
conversations.response:
Financial assistance for organizing a competition, you say? Well, I've got some good news and some not-so-good news for you!

According to the university's guidelines, fundraising activities involving selling goods are not allowed. However, you can submit a fundraising proposal and an approval letter from the respective charitable organization(s) to the DSTO (Dean of Students' Office) for endorsement. If approved, you can proceed with your fundraising plans.

Additionally, you'll need to submit a financial report, along with a valid receipt from the charitable organization, to DSTO (and the Students' Union if applicable) within two weeks after the fundraising event.

So, while there are some hoops to jump through, it's not impossible to get financial assistance for your competition. Just make sure to follow the university's guidelines and regulations carefully!

Source: student_organizations.txt

conversations.user_input: User: What are the consequences for violating student activity guidelines?
conversations.response:
According to the guidelines, if you fail to comply, you might face penalties such as a written warning for minor cases, suspension of booking rights, forced community services, termination of funding support or other privileges, disciplinary record, or other penalties that will be considered on a case-by-case basis. And, if you provide false information or incomplete information intentionally, you might get a more severe penalty. So, it's essential to follow the guidelines and consult with DSTO for specific guidance to avoid any trouble!

Source: data/student_organizations.txt
